I estimate a 7% chance the US Justice Department file criminal charges against Volkswagen by March 30. First, little information has been published recently that would indicate a high likelihood for DOJ charges against Volkswagen in the next month. Applying N (norms and protocols matter) from CHAMPS KNOW, the DOJ would first subpoena information that would allow them to build a case in the courts against Volkswagen. After this months long process occurred, the DOJ can then file charges. Historically, the DOJ does not rush through the process of opening cases, and often takes months to do so once information is subpoenaed. There is no reason to believe this norm would change, and since information has not yet been subpoenaed (with only one month to go before this question expires), it seems more likely that criminal charges won’t arise until the latter part of 2016 or early 2017.

With the trip to Germany by Obama, it would be a major diplomatic issue to begin criminal proceedings against one of the most powerful German companies and a strong point in their economy. While criminal charges may occur, extremely unlikely within the month.

It makes logical sense that in order for trade and investment barrier negotiations to be reached, Obama would be unwise to call on the Department of Justice to indict Volkswagen, an important German company, a month before this meeting. The trip is only intended to strengthen the relationship between the two countries. I do not expect criminal charges to be filed against Volkswagen before then.
